Chapter 5, Section 7: Discriminating Karma, as mentioned above, the bodhisattva abiding in certainty, from what stage is he called abiding in certainty?
What is he called certain about?
Verse:
From cultivating the karma of wondrous characteristics, the bodhisattva attains the name of certainty,
Born in good destinies and noble families, with complete male faculties and firm mindfulness.
Commentary:

From cultivating the karma that ripens in the thirty-two major marks of a great man, the bodhisattva is then called abiding in certainty, because from this time until becoming a buddha, he is always born in good destinies and noble families, etc.
Born in good destinies means born as a human or god, because in these destinies one mostly practices good and it is wonderful, thus they are called good destinies.
Within good destinies, he is always born in noble families, namely brÄhman or ká¹£atriya, very wealthy brÄhman families.

In noble families, the faculties are complete or incomplete, but those bodhisattvas always have superior faculties, always receive a male body, and are not even female, let alone receive the body of a eunuch or the like.
In each rebirth, they are always able to remember their past lives and the good deeds they have done.

They are always without discouragement, that is, with regard to benefiting and gladdening all sentient beings, at all times and by all means, their minds are without weariness, which is called being without discouragement.
Because of being without discouragement, they are said to be firm.

Isn't it the case that before cultivating the karma for the excellent characteristics, the bodhi mind is not yet irreversible, and one should be established in the stage of abiding in certainty? Why is it that only when the bodhisattva is in the stage of cultivating the karma for the excellent characteristics is he considered to have entered the stage of abiding in certainty?
At that time, humans and gods are just beginning to know it together, so previously it was only known by the gods.
Or at that time, one is heading towards the certainty of enlightenment, and previously it was only the certainty of enlightenment, not anything else.
What characteristics should one know in cultivating the karma for the excellent characteristics?
Verse:
In JambudvÄ«pa, a man facing the Buddha, the Buddha is the object of thought and thought-concomitants.
In other places, it takes a hundred kalpas to cultivate, each adorned with a hundred merits.
The treatise says:
Bodhisattvas can only cultivate and attract the karma for creating the excellent characteristics in JambudvÄ«pa, because the wisdom of this continent is the sharpest.
Only men, not women, etc., can do so, because at that time they have already transcended the state of women, etc.
This should not be said, because the meaning of always receiving a male body has already been shown in the previous verse.

When creating this karma, one only faces the Buddha, that is, personally seeing the Buddha's unique physical characteristics and marks, which are extremely wonderful and extraordinary, and wishes to give rise to thoughts that can attract this kind of karma. Without facing the TathÄgata, it is not possible to give rise to it.
This karma for creating excellent characteristics only takes the Buddha as the object of thought, because the Buddha is the object of admiration and virtue.
The karma that attracts excellent characteristics is only created by thought;
it is not created by cultivation, because it is not of the indeterminate realm, and the retribution that it attracts is bound to this realm.
It is not born of hearing, because that is weak.
It is also not innate, because it arises from added effort.
It is said that it can only be acquired in a body in which the perfections of giving, etc., have been fulfilled over three incalculable eons. It is only good born of added effort and not innate.
Only the remaining one hundred kalpas are creative and not many. Each of the excellent major marks is adorned with one hundred merits.

Here one hundred thoughts are called one hundred merits. That is, when one is about to create each of the major marks, one first generates fifty thoughts to purify the body as a vessel. Then one generates the karma that attracts one mark. After that, one again generates fifty good thoughts to adorn the attracting karma and cause it to be fulfilled.
The fifty thoughts are based on the ten kinds of action paths. Each of the ten action paths generates five thoughts.

As for the five kinds of volition that exist in the initial avoidance of the path of killing, the first is the volition of avoiding killing, the second is the volition of encouraging others, the third is the volition of praising others, the fourth is the volition of rejoicing, and the fifth is the volition of dedicating, that is, dedicating one's cultivation towards liberation.
Up to wrong views, each has five in the same way.
Other masters say:
Based on the ten paths of action, each arouses five kinds of good volition, superior, etc., each preceding and succeeding, like perfuming the meditative absorptions.
Other masters say:

Based on the ten paths of action, each arouses five kinds of volition, the first is the purity of the preparatory stage, the second is the purity of the fundamental stage, the third is the purity of the subsequent stage, the fourth is not harming through discursive thought, and the fifth is the recollection of acceptance.
There are also masters who say:
Each characteristic action serves as the condition for a volition never previously cultivated by the Buddha, and one hundred of these manifest and serve as its adornment.
What is the measure of each of these one hundred merits?
Some say:

The body of merit that is accumulated through the growth of merit over three incalculable eons gives rise to such immeasurable and innumerable superior blessings. Only the Buddha knows the measure of this.
Some say:
If one is born as a wheel-turning king through the power of karma, ruling the four continents with sovereignty, this is the measure of one blessing.
Some say:
If one becomes Åšakra, king of the gods, through the power of karma, ruling the two desire heavens with sovereignty, this is the measure of one blessing.
Some say:
Except for the blessings of bodhisattvas close to Buddhahood, the merit of all other beings is the measure of one blessing.
Other masters say:

The measure of this blessing is great or small. It should be said that when the world is about to form, the merit of all beings that gives rise to the great trichiliocosm is the measure of one blessing.
How many Buddhas did the Blessed One worship during the three incalculable eons when he was a bodhisattva?
A verse says:
In the three incalculable eons, he made offerings to 70,000 buddhas each,
And in order, made offerings to 6,000, 7,000 buddhas.
The treatise says:

In the first incalculable eon, he made offerings to 75,000 buddhas. In the second incalculable eon, he made offerings to 76,000 buddhas. In the third incalculable eon, he made offerings to 77,000 buddhas.
When each of the three incalculable eons was completed, and when he first gave rise to the resolve, what buddhas did he encounter?
The verse says:
When the three incalculable eons were completed, he encountered VipaÅ›yin,
DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, RatnaÅ›ikhin Buddha, and first ÅšÄkyamuni.
The treatise says:
As for in reverse order, it means from later to earlier.

That is to say, when the third incalculable eon was completed, the buddha he encountered and served was named VipaÅ›yin.ğŸ”½When the second eon was completed, the buddha he encountered and served was named DÄ«paá¹ƒkara.
When the first eon was completed, the buddha he encountered and served was named RatnaÅ›ikhin.
In the first incalculable eon, he first encountered Shakyamuni.
It is said that our World-Honored One, when first generating the mind of enlightenment, encountered a Bhagavan named Shakyamuni.
When that Buddha appeared, he was in the final eon. After his extinction, the true Dharma only remained for a thousand years.
At that time, our World-Honored One was the son of a potter. He gave rise to a sincere and pure mind towards that Buddha, anointed him with fragrant oil, and bathed him with fragrant water.
Having made offerings, he made a great vow, saying:
May I become a Buddha just like the present World-Honored One.
Therefore, the Tathagata is now exactly the same as him.
In what stage did our Shakyamuni Bodhisattva fully cultivate and perfect the perfections?
The verse says:ğŸ”½Merely out of compassion, he universally gave,
his body was cut apart but he was not angry,ğŸ”½he praised Dipankara Buddha,
then unsurpassed enlightenment,ğŸ”½the six perfections,
in these four stages,ğŸ”½one, two, and again one, two,
are cultivated and perfected in sequence.
The treatise states:
When a bodhisattva first generates the vow and practices giving, they are not yet able to give all things to all sentient beings, only giving with a compassionate mind.
Later, due to the power of habitual practice, their compassionate mind grows even stronger, and they are able to give to all sentient beings, though not all things.
When a bodhisattva universally gives everything to everyone, but only out of compassion, not seeking superior rebirth for themselves, at that point the perfection of giving is fully cultivated.

When a bodhisattva, though not yet free from desire and greed, has no trace of anger even when their body is being cut apart, at that point the perfections of morality and patience are fully cultivated.

When a bodhisattva, with vigorous effort, praises Buddha Tiá¹£ya for seven days and nights with a single verse, and thereby skips nine eons, at that point the perfection of effort is fully cultivated.

When a Bodhisattva, seated on the diamond throne, is about to ascend to supreme perfect enlightenment, he abides in the diamond-like concentration immediately before supreme enlightenment. At this point, the perfections of concentration and wisdom are fully cultivated.
Reason dictates that they are perfected only at this point, because at the time of attaining the knowledge of termination, they are perfected.
Because they each individually reach the other shore of perfection, these six are called perfections.
A scripture teaches that there are three meritorious works: meritorious works consisting of giving, meritorious works consisting of morality, and meritorious works consisting of meditation.
How are they established as meritorious works?
A verse says:ğŸ”½The three types of giving, morality, and meditation are each called meritorious works according to their application.
They are distinguished like the paths of action.
The treatise says:
The three types are all merit, either action or works, according to their application, as explained in the paths of action.
For example, in the case of the ten courses of action, there are some that are both action and path, and some that are path but not action.

Herein, there is that which is both merit and action and also a thing, there is that which is merit and action but not a thing, there is that which is merit and a thing but not action, and there is that which is only merit and neither action nor a thing.
First, in the category of giving, the two actions of body and speech are called merit, action, and a thing in the sense of the three meanings.

Because they are good, they are merit. Because they are created, they are also action. Because they are the door through which the volition that gives rise to and transforms the bodily and verbal actions occurs, they are also called a thing.
The volition that gives rise to them is only called merit and action. The dharmas that coexist with volition are only called merit.
Since the category of morality is only of the nature of bodily and verbal actions, they are all called merit, action, and a thing.

In the category of cultivation, loving-kindness is only called merit and a thing, because it is the cause of action. This is because the volition associated with loving-kindness creates it by taking loving-kindness as the door.
The precepts that coexist with loving-kindness are only called merit and action. The other coexisting dharmas are only called merit.
Compassion and so forth should all be examined in the same way.
Some say:
The word â€œmeritorious actionâ€ makes clear the meaning of merit, that is, merit is the activity that is manifested.
That is, giving, morality, and cultivation are the activities of meritorious action, because meritorious action is performed in order to accomplish these three.
Some say:
Only volition is the true meritorious action.
Meritorious action is the activity of giving, morality, and cultivation, because meritorious action occurs through these three as its gateway.
What is giving?
What result does giving bring?
Verse:
By this, abandoning is called giving, that is, for the sake of offering and benefiting,
Body, speech, and what gives rise to it, this brings about the result of great wealth.
Discussion:
Although the object abandoned and the means of abandoning can both be called giving, in this context the name â€œgivingâ€ is established only based on the means of abandoning.
That is, because the matter of abandoning is accomplished by means of this, the volition of abandoning is the true substance of giving.
Just as the object that is measured does not receive the name of measure, the name of measure is established based on the means of measuring.

Or for the sake of competition, hoarding, praise, or learning from others, following others, or out of affection and attachment, giving is also accomplished in this way. However, this is not the main meaning of what is said here.

In order to distinguish this, it is said that giving is for the sake of offerings and benefit. For one's own nirvana, it is only for the sake of offerings. For others, it is also for the sake of benefiting their great elements and faculties. When practicing giving, it is only for the sake of benefiting them.
What is meant by complete?
It refers to bodily and verbal actions, and what gives rise to them.
What gives rise to them?

It refers to the aggregate of non-greed that gives rise to this group, namely bodily and verbal actions, as well as the mind that gives rise to them, and what accompanies them is collectively called the essence of giving.
As a verse says:
If a person, with a pure mind, stops and practices giving,
This wholesome aggregate in that moment is generally established as giving.
It should be known that this kind of meritorious action of giving, even if dedicated towards liberation, also attains the fruit of separation.
Moreover, from a proximate perspective, it is definitely said that it only leads to the result of great wealth.
On what basis is this called great wealth?
Because the wealth is wonderful, vast, and cannot be taken away.
For whose benefit is giving practiced?
Verse:
For the benefit of self, others, both, or neither, one practices giving.
Commentary:

When the giver gives, they consider two benefits: first, for their own benefit, they give rise to wholesome roots that attract results; second, for the benefit of others, they give the great elements of the sense faculties.
There are two kinds of givers: those with afflictions and those without afflictions.
Those with afflictions are also of two kinds: those who have not yet abandoned craving for desire and those who have already abandoned craving for desire.
Among these two, each is of two kinds: the noble ones and ordinary beings.

Among them, the noble ones who have not yet abandoned craving for desire, and the ordinary beings who have not yet abandoned craving for desire, when making offerings to stupas, only benefit themselves, that is, they increase two kinds of wholesome roots:
First, it can attract great wealth as its result; second, it serves as the provision for attaining the supreme meaning.

For noble ones who have already become free from attachment to desire realm objects, offerings made to stupas, except for those that are to be experienced in the present life, do not attract great wealth, because they have already been able to transcend the realm of those karmic maturations forever.
But they are still able to serve as the provision for attaining the supreme meaning. Therefore, they are also called benefiting only oneself;
because they cannot benefit others' faculties and primary elements, they do not benefit others.

Those without afflictions, when making offerings to other sentient beings, only benefit others, that is, they are able to benefit others' faculties and primary elements, but do not increase their own two kinds of wholesome roots, except for those to be experienced in the present life.
Those with afflictions, when making offerings to other sentient beings, benefit both themselves and others;
those without afflictions, when making offerings to stupas, except for those to be experienced in the present life, do not benefit both.
Previously, it was generally stated that giving attracts great wealth. Now, the specific causes of the results of giving will be explained.
Verse:
The fruits of giving are distinguished due to the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field.
The treatise says:

Giving has distinctions due to three kinds of causes, namely, because of the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field, and because of the distinctions in giving, the fruits have distinctions.

As for the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field, it means that the superiority or inferiority of the giver, the object given, and the field in this kind of giving is different from other givers, objects given, and fields.
First, as for the differences in the giver, the verse says:
The giver is different due to faith, etc., practicing respectful giving, etc.,
Obtaining respect, vast love, appropriateness, and difficult to take away fruits.
The treatise says:

There are donors who have definite faith in cause and effect, there are donors who are uncertain about cause and effect, there are donors who act on impulse, there are donors who possess pure precepts, some who violate them slightly, and some who have no precepts at all, there are donors who are well-versed in the Buddha's teachings, some who are less learned, and some who have no learning at all, yet they practice giving.
Due to the differences in the virtues possessed by donors, such as faith, precepts, learning, etc., it is called difference in the master.
Because of the difference in the master, giving becomes differentiated, and due to the difference in giving, the results obtained are also different.
Those donors who possess such virtues and are able to practice giving in the proper way, such as with reverence, etc., will in turn obtain the four fruits of reverence, etc.
That is to say, if a donor practices giving with reverence, they will always be revered by others.
If one gives with one's own hands, one will be able to obtain vast wealth and enjoy it with delight.
If one gives at the proper time, one will obtain wealth at the proper time, because what is needed is at the proper time, not at other times.
If one gives without harming others, one will obtain wealth that is not destroyed by kings, fires, etc.
As for the differences in the wealth that is given, the verse states:
The differences in wealth are due to color, etc. One obtains a wonderful appearance and a good reputation.
The body is loved by the multitude and soft, with pleasant tactile sensations in accordance with the season.
The treatise states:
If the wealth that is given lacks or possesses color, smell, taste, and touch, one will accordingly obtain the results of a wonderful appearance, etc. that lack or possess these qualities.
That is to say, because the wealth that is given possesses color, one will obtain a wonderful appearance.
Because the smell is complete, one will obtain a good reputation, just as fragrance pervades all directions.
Because the taste is complete, one will be loved by the multitude, just as delicious flavors are loved by the multitude.
Because the tactile sensations are complete, one will obtain a soft body and tactile sensations that give rise to pleasant feelings in accordance with the season.
If any of these are lacking, the corresponding fruit will be diminished. In the same way, giving is also different due to the difference in color, fragrance, etc. of the objects given.
Because of the difference in objects given, the substance of giving and its fruit are all distinguished.
As for the difference in the field of giving, the verse says:
The difference in fields is due to realms, suffering, kindness, and virtue.
The treatise says:
The difference in fields is due to the difference in realms, suffering, kindness, and virtue. Because of the difference in fields, the fruit of giving is distinguished.
As for the difference in realms, the World-Honored One said:
If one gives to animals, one receives a hundred times the fruit. If one gives to those who violate precepts, one receives a thousand times the fruit.

As for the difference in suffering, it is as explained in the seven meritorious deeds based on material things, which first say one should give to guests, travelers, the sick, attendants, gardens, groves, regular meals, and cold and windy places, and give medicine according to the season.
It is also said that if a man or woman with perfect faith accomplishes these seven types of meritorious activities with basis, the merit they obtain cannot be measured.
Here, due to the difference in conditions, suffering has differences.
Due to the difference in the recipient, the fruit has differences.
As for the difference in kindness, it is like parents, teachers, and others who are kind, like bears, deer, and so forth.
The Jataka Sutra says that for those who are kind, the evil karma they create towards the kind has obvious results;
By this, one can infer the good of practicing gratitude.
As for the fruit definitely due to the difference in virtue, as stated in the sutra:
The fruit of giving to those who uphold precepts is a hundred thousand times greater, up to the fruit of giving to the Buddha being immeasurable.
Although all are immeasurable, there is still a little more, like the difference between a drop of water in the Ganges River and the great ocean.
Like comparing material giving, the giving of Dharma is supreme.
Within material giving, what is the most excellent?
The verse says:
Liberating the liberated bodhisattva, the eighth giving is supreme.
The treatise says:
If one gives to a field of liberation who is already liberated, among material gifts this is the most supreme.

If bodhisattvas with a superior intention equally wish to benefit and delight all beings, and practice giving for the sake of great enlightenment, although it is not giving to the liberated or a field of liberation, among the merits of giving this is the most supreme.
Apart from this, there are eight kinds of giving, and the merit of the eighth giving is also the most supreme.
What are the eight kinds of giving?

First, giving according to one's ability; second, giving out of fear; third, giving in return for kindness; fourth, giving in expectation of reward; fifth, giving out of habit; sixth, giving in hope of heaven; seventh, giving for the sake of fame; eighth, giving in order to adorn the mind, to assist the mind, to assist yoga, and to attain the supreme meaning.
As the World-Honored One said:ğŸ”½Giving to the noble ones has immeasurable fruits.
Can there be giving whose fruits are also immeasurable, even though it is not to the noble ones?
The verse says:
Parents, the sick, Dharma teachers, and bodhisattvas in their final birth,
Even if they are not saints, the fruits of giving to them are also immeasurable.
The treatise says:
Even if these five are ordinary beings, the giver can also reap immeasurable fruits.
Abiding in the final existence is called the final birth.
The Dharma teacher is included in the field of gratitude among the four fields.
Do all actions that can produce immeasurable fruits have equal superior and inferior categories?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
Due to six causes, all actions become light and heavy.
What are the six?
The verse says:
Post-action, field, root, preparatory action, intention, and aspiration,
By these lower and higher, actions become lower and higher.
The treatise says:
Post-action means, having done this action, either suddenly or repeatedly following it.
The field means creating good or evil towards them.
The fundamental [karmas] refer to the fundamental karmic paths.
The preparatory [karmas] refer to the body and speech that lead to them.
The volition refers to the completion of that karmic path.
The intention refers to the intention, I should create such and such.
If all six causes are of the highest level, this karma is the heaviest. The opposite of this is the lightest. Apart from this, the intermediate [karmas] are neither the lightest nor the heaviest.
As the sutra says:
Carefully contemplating and creating karma is called creating and also called increasing.
For what reason is karma called increasing?
Because of five causes.
What are the five?
The verse says:
Because of careful consideration, completion, no regret, no antidote,
Accompanied, and with ripening, this karma is called increasing.
The treatise says:
Because of careful consideration means creating after careful consideration, not creating with an impulsive thought, and also not creating without any thought at all.
Because of completion means that the amount of karma should lead to a bad realm of rebirth.
When this action is completed, it is called â€œincrease,â€ while the rest are only â€œmaking.â€
Because there is no remorse as an antidote, it means that there is no action with remorse as an antidote.
Because there is a companion, it means that when one does unwholesome actions, unwholesomeness is the companion.
Because of retribution, it means that even if the time is not fixed, it is definitely with retribution. Wholesome actions are the opposite of this.
It should be known that other than this, they are only called â€œmaking.â€
As explained above, those who have not yet freed themselves from desires and so forth, making offerings to stupas only benefits themselves.
Since there is no one to receive the offerings, how can the merit of giving be accomplished?
Verse:
The merit of giving to stupas is like the merit of loving-kindness, etc., without a receiver.
Treatise:
We do not only allow that the merit of giving is accomplished only when the received property is received and used by the receiver.
What is allowed?
It is said that the merit of giving is roughly of two kinds: one is giving, the other is receiving.
The merit of abandonment is the merit that arises from the mere abandonment of wealth by a good mind.
The merit of enjoyment is the merit that arises from the enjoyment of the object given by the recipient of the gift.
Although there is no merit of enjoyment in offerings made to stupas, there is merit of abandonment.
However, the merit of abandonment is accomplished when one first abandons wealth, because it is the antidote to greed, and because it is produced by the volition that accompanies non-greed.
After abandoning wealth, whether the recipient enjoys the gift or not, the merit of the gift is not lost.
If it were not so, then if one makes offerings of necessities to the Sangha or to individual monks, and the objects are not used and are lost or destroyed,
in this case the donor's objects would be wasted, and the merit of the gift would not arise, because there would be no future result.
If the recipient does not use the gift, how does merit arise?
Although there is no merit of enjoyment, there is merit of acceptance.
Since there is no acceptance in the case of stupas, how does merit arise?
What evidence is there that merit arises only through receiving?
Because there is no appropriation of benefit without receiving.
This is not definite evidence.
Why is this?
Because merit also arises from cultivating loving-kindness, etc.

That is, when cultivating the concentration of loving-kindness, one equally arouses the intention to bring happiness to all sentient beings. Even though there is no recipient and no appropriation of benefit, much merit arises due to the power of superior resolve.
The same is so for the attainment of merit from cultivating the concentrations of compassion, etc.
The merit of giving to a caitya should be of the same class.
Even though there is no recipient and no appropriation of benefit, much merit arises due to the power of one's own mind.
However, it is not wasted.
The act of giving and paying respect must give rise to the act of giving rise to superior thoughts. Only superior thoughts can give rise to superior merit.
There are those who raise objections, saying:
When the seeds of karmic actions are planted in a good field, the fruits that are born are certainly pleasant. When planted in an evil field, the fruits should not be pleasant.
This objection is unreasonable.
Why is it unreasonable?
The verse states:
Even in an evil field, there are pleasant fruits, because the fruit is not inverted with respect to the seed.
The treatise states:
It is clearly seen that in a field, the fruit is not inverted with respect to the seed. Bitter fruits will never be born from the seeds of a pomegranate.
Sweet fruits will not be born from the seeds of a neem tree.

It is not due to the power of the field that the fruit is inverted with respect to the seed. Rather, it is due to the fault of the field that the seeds that are planted either produce few fruits or no fruits at all.
In the same way, although one plants giving in an evil field, due to the giver's mind of benefiting and bringing happiness to others, only pleasant fruits are born and not unpleasant ones.
The classification of giving has already been discussed. The classification of precepts will now be discussed.
The verse states:
Abstaining from offenses and prohibitions is called precepts, each having two types.
Not due to the destruction of the causes of offenses, but based on the purification of antidotes and cessation, etc.
The treatise states:
As for the term â€œviolating precepts,â€ it refers to all unwholesome forms, from killing living beings up to frivolous speech.
Here, natural offenses are established as the name â€œviolating precepts.â€

Prohibited means what is prohibited by the Buddha, namely eating at improper times, etc. Although not natural offenses, the Buddha prohibited them with a special intention to protect the true Dharma and sentient beings. Violating them after accepting the precepts is also called violating precepts, but in order to distinguish them from natural offenses, they are simply called prohibited.

Abstaining from natural and prohibited [acts] is both called precepts, each of which has two aspects, namely expressed and unexpressed, because they take bodily and verbal actions as their intrinsic nature.
Precepts endowed with four virtues are called pure. If any are lacking, they are not called pure.
As for the four virtues, the first is not being destroyed by violating precepts.
As for violating precepts, it means intentionally committing offenses.
The second is not being destroyed by their causes.
Their causes refer to the afflictions and secondary afflictions such as greed, etc.
The third is relying on their antidotes, namely relying on the foundations of mindfulness, etc., because these can counteract violating precepts and their causes.
Fourth, it is based on cessation, that is, it is based on nirvÄá¹‡a and is directed toward nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is not a possession.
The word â€œetc.â€ indicates that there are other explanations.
Some say:

The purity of morality is due to five causes: first, the purity of the fundamental precepts; second, the purity of the subsidiary precepts; third, not being harmed by discursive thought; fourth, being embraced by mindfulness; fifth, being directed toward quiescence.
Having explained the class of morality, we will now explain the class of cultivation.
Verse:
Concentration and good are called cultivation, because they can thoroughly perfume the mind.
Treatise:
Concentration and good means that which is of the same nature as concentration and that which accompanies it. This is called cultivation, because it can thoroughly perfume the mind.
Cultivation has the meaning of perfuming, like flowers perfuming sesame.
This means that the good of concentration can thoroughly perfume the mind-continuum, causing it to become virtuous, unlike the good of non-concentration. Therefore, it alone is called cultivation.
Having explained the merit of giving that can attract great wealth, what are the rewards attracted by the two classes of morality and cultivation?
Verse:
The superiority of precepts and cultivation respectively lead to rebirth in the heavens and liberation.
The treatise says:
Precepts lead to rebirth in the heavens, cultivation leads to liberation.

The word superior is used to show that it is spoken from the perspective of superiority. This means that giving can also lead to rebirth in the heavens, but in terms of superiority, precepts are spoken of;
Upholding precepts can also lead to the fruit of separation from defilements, but in terms of superiority, cultivation is spoken of.
In the same way, upholding precepts can also lead to great wealth, but in terms of superiority, giving is spoken of. This should be understood by analogy.
The sÅ«tras say:
